description: From post-classical Latin alembrottus, likely derived from an Arabic term; further etymology uncertain.

entries.meaning: (archaic) The "salt of wisdom" of the alchemists, a double salt composed of the chlorides of ammonium and mercury, formerly used as a stimulant.
examples: It contains about 2500 inhabitants, parations of alembroth salt, given by the old writers of is a marquisate, and has 13 parishes belonging to its district
